div.p: Royal Geographical Society of Australasia (Victorian Branch), box 52(a), Royal Historical Society of Victoria, Melbourne.
M's letter, together with various other documents relating to the founding of the Victorian Branch of the RGSA, has been inserted at the front of the Branch's first minute book. 9/8/83.

It is pleasing to observe, dear Mr MacDonald, that you take the initiative in organizing a Victorian branch of the geographic Society of Australia.
See A. Macdonald to M (and others), 8 August 1883. — When at the preliminary meeting for the constitution of the Society in Sydney I was honored telegraphically with a request to accept the Presidency of the Society, but saw my way not clear for undertaking presidential duties, however honorable, I had at once an opportunity of suggesting that affiliated Societies should be formed in each of the colonies of Australia, which suggestion was adopted by the Council in Sydney. Irrespective of my devotion to geographic researches, which I have frequently promoted during the 36 years of my uninterrupted stay in Australia, I feel specially bound to aid, so far as I can, the local branch of the Society here; therefore you can at any time command my counsels, though my affairs in life, my official obligations and other circumstances may prevent me from sharing in any active administrat[ive] duties of the Socie[ty.]
editorial additions — words partly obscured by binding. See also M to A. Macdonald, 20 September 1883.
